citations.narrative:
In an enclosure housing three Patagonian cavies there is a wall on the right-hand side as you walk in that is covered in
chicken wire. This wire has peeled loose at the bottom, exposing multiple sharp points that pose an injury risk for the
animals contained within. The sharp points need to be removed or secured. The licensee should ensure that all surfaces
are maintained and kept in good repair at all times in order to protect the animals from potential injuries.
Corrected at the time of the inspection.
In the Jacob's sheep enclosure, the barn used for shelter during inclement weather is in need of immediate repair. The
edges and center section of the four by eight sheet of plywood on the outside wall that faces the public drive thru portion
of the park, have been chewed and roughened by the sheep. Towards the front opening of barn, there is a hole that has
been created by the sheep from chewing through the plywood. This hole is round in shape and approximately twelve
inches across at its largest point. Nineteen animals are in contact with the affected surfaces. The integrity and structural
strength of all chewed wood surfaces are affected. The potential exists for the splintered wood ends to become ingested
causing potential digestion problems. Also, on the back/rear portion of the barn there are two round, metal pipes about
one to two inches in diameter protruding approximately twelve to twenty-four inches out into the opening of the enclosure
from behind the barn. These protruding, exposed pipes could cause a serious injury to the sheep. The licensee must
ensure all surfaces are structurally sound and maintained in good repair at all times.
Corrected at the time of the inspection.

In an outdoor enclosure housing three cavies, there was an accumulation of feces just outside of the wire at the bottom of
the enclosure. The pile of feces was also spilling over and falling into the covered portion of the cavy enclosure and
coming into contact with the animals. Excreta and feces shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary
to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. The
licensee is to ensure that an adequate cleaning and sanitization schedule is maintained at all times.
Corrected at the time of the inspection.

In an enclosure housing two male peacocks there was an electric extension cord draped and hanging down into the
enclosure where the peacocks had access to it. It was not plugged in or being used at the time, but still provided a risk for
injury to the birds contained. Power cords or extension cords should be protected securely or in a location that the birds
cannot access. The facility must ensure that the enclosure is safe for the animals at all times.
Corrected at the time of the inspection.

In an outdoor enclosure housing two ring-necked pheasants, the water receptacle had an algae looking substance in it.
You could not visualize the bottom of the receptacle through the drinking water. Contaminated water that is no longer
potable could lead to potential health risks. Water receptacles containing an algae looking substance indicates a lack of
cleaning and sanitation. They must be sanitized as often as necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food
waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. The licensee must ensure all water receptacles are cleaned and sanitized
more often for the health and well-being of the birds at all times.
Corrected at the time of the inspection.

In an outdoor enclosure housing two emus, the cement pond/pool that was in the center of the enclosure had an algae
looking substance in it. The water was a very dark, greenish brown color. You could not visualize the light blue concrete
bottom of the pond/pool through the water. Contaminated water that is no longer potable could lead to potential health
risks. The emus had access to clean drinking water located in a different receptacle, but an emu was observed drinking
from the contaminated pond/pool during the inspection. This water feature can be detrimental to the health of the birds
contained therein. Pools or ponds containing water with an algae looking substance indicates a lack of adequate cleaning
and sanitization. They must be sanitized as often as necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste,
excreta, and other disease hazards. The licensee must ensure all water receptacles and water features are cleaned and
sanitized more often for the health and well-being of the birds at all times.
Corrected at the time of the inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
In an enclosure housing three Patagonian cavies there is a wall on the right-hand side as you walk in that is covered in 
chicken wire. This wire has peeled loose at the bottom, exposing multiple sharp points that pose an injury risk for the 
animals contained within. The sharp points need to be removed or secured. The licensee should ensure that all surfaces 
are maintained and kept in good repair at all times in order to protect the animals from potential injuries.  
Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
 
In the Jacob's sheep enclosure, the barn used for shelter during inclement weather is in need of immediate repair. The 
edges and center section of the four by eight sheet of plywood on the outside wall that faces the public drive thru portion 
of the park, have been chewed and roughened by the sheep. Towards the front opening of barn, there is a hole that has 
been created by the sheep from chewing through the plywood. This hole is round in shape and approximately twelve 
inches across at its largest point. Nineteen animals are in contact with the affected surfaces. The integrity and structural 
strength of all chewed wood surfaces are affected. The potential exists for the splintered wood ends to become ingested 
causing potential digestion problems. Also, on the back/rear portion of the barn there are two round, metal pipes about 
one to two inches in diameter protruding approximately twelve to twenty-four inches out into the opening of the enclosure 
from behind the barn. These protruding, exposed pipes could cause a serious injury to the sheep. The licensee must 
ensure all surfaces are structurally sound and maintained in good repair at all times. 
Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
In an outdoor enclosure housing three cavies, there was an accumulation of feces just outside of the wire at the bottom of 
the enclosure. The pile of feces was also spilling over and falling into the covered portion of the cavy enclosure and 
coming into contact with the animals. Excreta and feces shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary 
to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. The 
licensee is to ensure that an adequate cleaning and sanitization schedule is maintained at all times. 
Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
3.153(a)(1)(ii)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures.

In an enclosure housing two male peacocks there was an electric extension cord draped and hanging down into the 
enclosure where the peacocks had access to it. It was not plugged in or being used at the time, but still provided a risk for 
injury to the birds contained. Power cords or extension cords should be protected securely or in a location that the birds 
cannot access. The facility must ensure that the enclosure is safe for the animals at all times.  
Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
3.156  Repeat
   
Watering 
In an outdoor enclosure housing two ring-necked pheasants, the water receptacle had an algae looking substance in it. 
You could not visualize the bottom of the receptacle through the drinking water. Contaminated water that is no longer 
potable could lead to potential health risks. Water receptacles containing an algae looking substance indicates a lack of 
cleaning and sanitation. They must be sanitized as often as necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food 
waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. The licensee must ensure all water receptacles are cleaned and sanitized 
more often for the health and well-being of the birds at all times.  
Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
3.157(a) 
   
Water quality. 
In an outdoor enclosure housing two emus, the cement pond/pool that was in the center of the enclosure had an algae 
looking substance in it. The water was a very dark, greenish brown color. You could not visualize the light blue concrete 
bottom of the pond/pool through the water. Contaminated water that is no longer potable could lead to potential health 
risks. The emus had access to clean drinking water located in a different receptacle, but an emu was observed drinking 
from the contaminated pond/pool during the inspection. This water feature can be detrimental to the health of the birds 
contained therein. Pools or ponds containing water with an algae looking substance indicates a lack of adequate cleaning 
and sanitization. They must be sanitized as often as necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, 
excreta, and other disease hazards. The licensee must ensure all water receptacles and water features are cleaned and 
sanitized more often for the health and well-being of the birds at all times.  
Corrected at the time of the inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.

species.common: GRAY WOLF / GREY WOLF / TIMBER WOLF
